Question_1.Context: The study aimed to identify bacterial contaminants in Prunus rootstock tissue cultures and determine effective nanomaterial concentrations for eliminating Curtobacterium sp. strain A7_M15 without harming explants.
Question_1.Question: What was the main objective of the study?
Question_1.B: Determining the impact of antibiotics on bacterial contamination
Question_1.C: Isolating and identifying bacterial contaminants in Prunus rootstock tissue cultures
Question_1.D: Testing the effect of nanomaterials on plant growth
Question_1.Source: The aim of this study was to identify the isolates representing the frequent bacterial contaminants of Prunus rootstock tissue cultures...

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the effectiveness of two nanocomposites, reduced graphene oxide–copper–silver and silver–selenium, for eliminating Curtobacterium sp. contamination in Gisela 5 rootstock tissue cultures.
Question_2.Question: Which nanocomposites showed 100% inhibition of bacterial plaque formation on culture medium?
Question_2.Source: Both nanocomposites showed 100% inhibition of bacterial plaque formation on culture medium at concentrations of 100, 200 and 400 mg L-1 Ag...

Question_3.Context: The study assessed the reduction in Curtobacterium sp. quantity on culture medium after treatment with nanocomposites.
Question_3.Question: By what percentage was the quantity of Curtobacterium sp. reduced after treatment with reduced graphene oxide–silver–copper at a concentration of 200 mg L-1 Ag?
Question_3.Source: The quantity of Curtobacterium sp. on culture medium assessed using cfu enumeration was reduced by 92%...

Question_4.Context: The study found that Curtobacterium sp. was detected in donor Gisela 5 plants, indicating a specific characteristic of this bacterium.
Question_4.Question: What characteristic was mentioned regarding Curtobacterium sp. in the study?
Question_4.A: It is an obligately anaerobic bacterium
Question_4.Source: Curtobacterium sp. was detected in donor Gisela 5 plants, indicating an endophytic character of this bacterium.

Question_5.Context: The study evaluated the impact of nanocomposites on the dry weight of explants.
Question_5.Question: What was the observed effect of nanocomposites at 100 or 200 mg L-1 Ag on the surface covered by plants?
Question_5.Source: The dry weight of explants was not negatively affected by the application of nanocomposites regardless of concentration...

Question_6.Context: The study concluded that reduced graphene oxide–silver–copper and silver–selenium nanocomposites effectively limited the presence of Curtobacterium sp. in micropropagated Prunus rootstock.
Question_6.Question: What was the main conclusion regarding the nanocomposites tested in the study?
Question_6.B: They had no effect on bacterial contamination
Question_6.C: They effectively limited the presence of Curtobacterium sp.
Question_6.Source: Reduced graphene oxide–silver–copper and silver–selenium nanocomposites at 200 mg L-1 Ag effectively limited the Curtobacterium sp. presence...

Question_7.Context: The study highlighted the importance of identifying bacterial isolates before implementing measures to prevent their occurrence.
Question_7.Question: Why is it important to identify bacterial isolates in tissue cultures?
Question_7.B: To adjust proper measures to avoid their occurrence
Question_7.Source: The effective elimination of bacterial contaminants in in vitro cultures needs to be, in some cases, preceded by the identification of present isolates, which can help to adjust proper measures to avoid their occurrence...

Question_8.Context: The study utilized the Biolog Microstation System and the GEN III MicroPlate test panel to analyze the phenotypic fingerprint of the Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 isolate.
Question_8.Question: What method was used to analyze the phenotypic fingerprint of the Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 isolate?
Question_8.Source: For the analysis of the Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 isolate phenotypic fingerprint, the Biolog Microstation System and the GEN III MicroPlate test panel...

Question_9.Context: The study involved whole-genome sequencing of the Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 isolate.
Question_9.Question: What was used for whole-genome sequencing of the Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 isolate?
Question_9.Source: The quantified library was sequenced on an Illumina platform according to the effective library concentration and data amount needed...

Question_10.Context: The study tested six nanoparticles and nanocomposites against Curtobacterium sp. A7_M15 in in vitro assays.
Question_10.Question: Which nanomaterial was NOT used in the experiment?
Question_10.Source: Six nanoparticles and nanocomposites selected for the experiment were provided by the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry...
